Chronic bronchitis is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years.

The single most important cause is cigarette smoking. The distinctive features of chronic bronchitis are as follows:

  • Hypersecretion of mucus

  • Goblet-cell hyperplasia

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman was diagnosed with Burkitt lymphoma. Cytogenetic studies demonstrated a t (8;14) chromosomal translocation. Which of the following best explains the role of this translocation in the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
The activation of the proto-oncogene MYC due to translocation is mainly responsible for the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma.

In Burkitt lymphoma, the MYC gene is translocated from its normal locus 8q24 to chromosome 14q32. The MYC gene at its normal locus is controlled and expressed in actively dividing cells. When the MYC gene is moved to 14q32, it is usually placed close to the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) gene. This movement is associated with the loss of regulatory sequences of the MYC gene, which are replaced by the control regions of the IGH gene, which is highly expressed in the B cells. The translocation is denoted as t (8;14) (q24; q32).

As a result, the MYC coding sequence is intact with the loss of regulatory control. The activation of the proto-oncogene leads to overexpression of the MYC protein, which is responsible for the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.text:
The image given below shows the mechanism of a component of the immune system's first line of defense against infection. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the release of these substances from the cell?

SLE- Systemic lupus erythematosus

choices.text: It results in the loss of nucleus.
It is effective only against bacteria.
It is implicated in the pathogenesis of  SLE.

questions.solution:
The gif shows fibrous neutrophilic extracellular traps (NETs) released from a neutrophil. NETs are mainly effective against bacteria and fungi.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps are networks of extracellular fibers that provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at the site of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are the meshwork of nuclear chromatin of neutrophils. The loss of nuclei leads to the death of the neutrophils. They concentrate on antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to fight against bacteria and fungi (not viruses). They are detected in the blood during sepsis. They are produced by neutrophils in response to

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

Note: The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found to have colonic cancer on routine colonoscopy and biopsy. His father had developed a similar colonic cancer and died at the age of 40. His family history is remarkable for endometrial and urothelial cancer. There is no history of familial adenomatous polyposis. Abnormality in which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is responsible for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Regulated genomic instability in lymphoid cells

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome/Hereditary non-polyposis colonic cancer (HNPCC). HNPCC results from a defect in the DNA mismatch repair system.

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant disorder that leads to the development of carcinoma in the cecum and proximal colon. One defective copy of the gene is inherited while the other gene undergoes a loss of function mutation.  

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function is lost leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome and microsatellite instability. A microsatellite is a sequence of 1-6 nucleotides found repeated throughout the genome. They are found in normal individuals at a constant length. In patients with DNA mismatch repair, these lengths are variable leading to mutated alleles. 

Other options: 

Option A: Patients with regulated genomic instability in lymphoid cells develop T and B cell neoplasia. 

Option C: Patients with a defect in the nucleotide excision repair pathway develop xeroderma pigmentosum.

Option D: Patients with defects in the homologous recombination DNA repair system may develop Bloom syndrome, ataxia-telangiectasia, and Fanconi anemia.

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the OPD with complaints of swelling in his thigh. Radiographs show a radiolucent center and surrounding irregular bone formation. CT shows a well-circumscribed mass within muscle with areas of bright calcification. A diagnosis of myositis ossificans is made. The most likely pathological mechanism associated with this is:

choices.text: High levels of prostaglandins within the nidus causing local inflammation
Production of osteoid matrix by the malignant cells
Metaplasia of fibroblast and bone formation
Inflammation, bone necrosis and reactive new bone formation

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette described here is of myositis ossificans and the pathology associated is metaplasia of fibroblast and bone formation.

Myositis ossificans is a reactive lesion occurring in the soft tissues. It is characterized by fibrous, osseous, and cartilaginous proliferation of the subperiosteal hematoma. This is later followed by metaplastic changes.

High levels of prostaglandin E2 and prostacyclin within the nidus causing local inflammation and vasodilation is seen in osteoid osteoma.

Production of an osteoid matrix by the malignant cells is seen in osteosarcoma.

Inflammation, suppuration, bone necrosis, reactive new bone formation and ultimately, resolution and healing are seen in osteomyelitis.

questions.text: The image given below shows an H&E-stained section of a lung tumor. The immunohistochemical studies of this tumor are most likely to express which of the following tumor markers?
questions.solution:
The above H&E stained histopathological image of a lung tumor shows keratin pearls suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Cytokeratins are the tumor markers that are most likely to be expressed.

Cytokeratins are the intermediate filaments expressed by epithelial cells. The presence of cytokeratins on immunohistochemistry suggests a carcinoma of epithelial origin. Tumors of epithelial origin include squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma etc.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly seen in men and has an increased risk with smoking. The tumor appears like a cauliflower-like mass that is gray-white, firm to hard, and bulky with hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathological features include keratinization in the form of squamous pearls. The cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis. 

Option B: Calretinin serves as a marker for mesothelioma.

Option C: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker for colon carcinoma and other malignancies including the pancreas, stomach, and heart.

questions.text: A child had recurrent bouts of infections. The diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease was made using the nitroblue tetrazolium test. This test assesses the functions of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The nitroblue tetrazolium test assesses the function of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN).

Nitroblue tetrazolium assay is used as a diagnostic test, particularly for chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). It tests the reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in neutrophils and monocytes.

Chronic granulomatous disease is a rare X-linked recessive disease. It is characterized by the impaired phagocytic killing of microorganisms by neutrophils and macrophages. Defects in NADPH oxidase lead to defective production of reactive oxygen species after phagocytosis.

These patients have frequent infections by catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus, Burkholderia cepacia complex, Nocardia, Aspergillus, etc. Recurrent folliculitis may prompt early diagnosis of the condition. Following these infections, there is extensive inflammation and suppuration despite antibiotic therapy.

Other features include aphthous ulcers, inflammation of the nares, and granulomas. Granulomas can cause obstruction of the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tracts. Autoimmune complications like immune thrombocytopenic purpura and juvenile idiopathic arthritis may also occur.

Management of CGD is mainly treating infections with antibiotics or antifungals depending on the cause. Granulomas are sensitive to steroids and glucocorticoids can be given. 

Other options:

Options B and C: B and T lymphocytes can be assessed by lymphocyte phenotyping. It is useful in the diagnosis of T-cell immunodeficiencies and agammaglobulinemia.

Option D: Complement can be assessed by CH50 and AP50, which are useful in diagnosing complement deficiencies.

Related Pearl: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.

 It can be:

  • X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or
  • Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text:
A young man undergoes partial hepatectomy as a part of living-donor hepatic transplantation. Which among the following is true about the regeneration of the liver?
  1. Two major mechanisms: Proliferation of remaining hepatocytes and repopulation from progenitor cells
  2. Hepatocyte proliferation occurs in 4 distinct stages.
  3. The priming phase includes production of IL - 6 by stellate cells
  4. During the termination phase, hepatacytes return to quiesence
  5. Progenitor cells reside in canals of Hering
questions.solution:
Among the given statements, 1, 4, and 5 are true about the regeneration of the liver.

The human liver regenerates by two major mechanisms :

  1. Proliferation of remaining hepatocytes
  2. Repopulation from progenitor cells.

Proliferation of hepatocytes:

This process is triggered by the combined actions of cytokines and growth factors and occurs in 3 distinct stages.

  • Priming stage: Cytokines like IL - 6 are produced by the Kupffer cells and act on hepatocytes to make them sensitive to growth factor signals.
  • Growth factor phase: HGF and TGF-α act on primed hepatocytes to stimulate cell metabolism and entry into the cell cycle. 
  • Termination phase: The hepatocytes return to quiescence with the involvement of antiproliferative factors like TGF-β

Regeneration from progenitor cells :

In situations where the proliferative capacity of hepatocytes is impaired, such as after chronic liver injury or inflammation, progenitor cells(oval cells) in the liver contribute to repopulation.

Oval cells are seen in the liver. These are liver stem cells located in the canals of Hering (structures that connect bile ductules to parenchymal hepatocytes).

A 55-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. The biopsy findings of H&E staining and immunohistochemistry for BCL2 are given in the images below. The results of immunophenotyping of the cells are as follows: CD19+, CD20+, CD10+, and CD5-. What is the translocation seen in this disease?

H&E: Hematoxyline and eosin
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of follicular lymphoma. The majority of follicular lymphomas have the characteristic t(14;18) translocation.

Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal center.

This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

On histopathology, the lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions: 

  • Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm
  • Centroblasts - large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm

In most cases, there is a majority of centrocytes.

Other options:

Option B: t(9;22) results in Philadelphia chromosome, which causes chronic myeloid leukemia.

Option C: t(8;14) is seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

Option D: t(11,14) is seen in mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text: The most common gene mutation in autosomal recessive hereditary spherocytosis is:
questions.solution:
Most common gene mutation in autosomal recessive HS: Spectrin

Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by inherited defects in the proteins stabilizing the red cell membrane.

Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane.

This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The non-deformable spherocytes are trapped in the splenic cords and phagocytosed by macrophages.

Note:

  • Most common mode of inheritance of HS: Autosomal dominant
  • Most common gene mutation in autosomal dominant HS: Ankyrin > Band 3
  • Most common gene mutation in autosomal recessive HS: Spectrin
  • Most severe form of HS: Spectrin (recessive)

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male complained of fatigue for the past 1 year. Examination revealed massive splenomegaly. His blood workup shows the following findings. Which of the following is the most sensitive investigation in this case?
  • Anemia
  • Total leucocyte count - 1,50,000/microL
  • Peripheral blood smear - 
    • Neutrophils- 60%
    • Basophils- 6%
    • Eosinophils - 4%
    • Myeloblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes
  • Myeloid to erythroid ratio- 18:1
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with fatigue, splenomegaly, and the peripheral blood smear findings are suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia(CML). The BCR-ABL gene which is specific for CML is detected by fluorescence in situ hybridization(FISH) or polymerase chain reaction(PCR) based tests.

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative disorder with the peak incidence in the fifth to sixth decade of life. The chimeric BCR-ABL gene is created by a reciprocal (9;22)(q34;q11) translocation(Philadelphia chromosome). This BCR-ABL gene distinguishes CML from other myeloproliferative disorders and is detected by fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

Clinical features:

Mild to moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia. Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis. Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

Peripheral blood:

  • Leukocytosis with leukocyte count, often exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3, which consists predominantly of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • Blasts are usually less than 10% of the circulating cells.
  • Platelet count is usually increased

Bone Marrow:

  • Markedly hypercellular marrow because of massively increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors. There is usually an elevated proportion of eosinophils and basophils.
  • There is also an increase in megakaryocytes and usually include small, dysplastic forms and erythroid progenitors are present in normal or mildly decreased numbers. Typically there is an increased reticulin deposition, but overt marrow fibrosis is rare early in the course.
  • Sea-blue histiocytes - These are scattered macrophages with abundant wrinkled,green-blue cytoplasm.

Other options:

Immunophenotyping and flow cytometry: Flow cytometry refers to the measurement of cellular antigens as they flow in a fluid stream. Immunophenotyping is employed using labeled antibodies against specific epitopes of cellular antigens. The technique that is usually used in immunophenotyping is flow cytometry. It has a limited role in the diagnosis of CML. It is mainly used in identifying CML blast transformation.

LAP score: Leucocyte alkaline phosphatase(LAP) score is decreased in cases of CML. It is only a first-line test in the diagnosis of CML and the diagnosis needs to be confirmed by other tests including bone marrow biopsy, molecular diagnostics, and cytogenetic analysis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with Down's syndrome is brought to the Medicine OPD by his sister who complains that he has been easily confused and forgetful about his daily activities recently. A provisional diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease is made. Which of the following genes is primarily responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
An increased copy number of the APP gene, which codes for the Aβ protein, is seen in Down's Syndrome (trisomy 21) leading to its overexpression, and that overexpression of APP may lead to the elevated levels of Aβ in Down's Syndrome leading to the development of Alzheimer’s disease. 

 

Alzheimer’s disease is associated with mutations in chromosomes 1, 14, 19, and 21.

    • APP gene on chromosome 21Trisomy 21 (Down’s syndrome): Extra dose of the APP gene on chromosome 21 is the initiating cause of AD in adult Down’s syndrome and results in excess cerebral amyloid production. 
    • Families with early-onset familial AD (FAD) have point mutations in APP.
  • Presenilin-1 (PS-1) is on chromosome 14 and encodes a protein called S182.
    • Presenilin-2 (PS-2) is on chromosome 1 and encodes a protein called STM2.PS-1 is involved in the cleavage of APP at the γ secretase site and mutations in either gene (PS-1 or APP) may disturb γ-secretase cleavage. 
    • Mutations in PS-1 are the most common cause of early-onset FAD (40–70% of all cases).
    • Mutations in PS-1 tend to produce AD with an earlier age of onset (mean onset 45 years) and a shorter, more rapidly progressive course (mean duration 6–7 years) than the disease caused by mutations in PS-2 (mean onset 53 years; duration 11 years).
  • Apo ε gene on chromosome 19: Three alleles: ε2, ε3, and ε4. The Apo ε4 allele confers an increased risk of AD in the general population, including sporadic and late-onset familial forms.

Mutations in the gene encoding copper­zinc superoxide dismutase (SOD1) on chromosome 21 is associated with Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). ALS is a progressive disorder in which there is a loss of the upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem. Inheritance is mostly autosomal dominant.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with a swelling on the back of his forearm as shown in the image below. He reported it to be growing in size and found it cosmetically unacceptable. On examination, the slip sign was positive. It was removed by a resident doctor and sent for a histopathology examination. The content within the tumor is best stained by?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image point to a diagnosis of lipoma. It's a tumor of mature adipocytes and is stained by sudan black B.

Lipomas are one of the commonest benign soft tissue tumors of adult. They arise in the subcutaneous tissue of limbs or trunk. They are soft, mobile and generally painless. Slip sign is a clinical sign to demonstrate the mobility of the tumor in the subcutaneous plane. They are treated by simple excision.

Liposarcomas are their malignant counterparts, with multiple recurrences unless adequately excised.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 6 months. She says that it has increased in size over the last 1 month. Investigations reveal elevated TSH levels. Histopathological examination is done, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and image showing Hurthle cells are suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. 

In this condition, the following microscopic features are seen:

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed germinal centers
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles 
  • The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (oncocytes)
    • This is called oncocytic metaplasia
    • These cells are called Hurthle cells
    • Ultrastructurally, these cells have numerous mitochondria

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in women between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Note: Oncocytes can arise in various tissues and are referred to as follows: 

  • Hurthle cells/ Ashkenazy cells - thyroid gland
  • Oxyphilic cells - parotid gland
  • Apocrine metaplasia - breast

questions.text: The histopathological image shown below is taken from the lung autopsy specimen of a patient who died of interstitial pulmonary fibrosis. What is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:

Asbestos bodies are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods with a translucent center. These bodies consist of asbestos fibers coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material. Asbestos bodies are formed when macrophages phagocytose the asbestos fibers. The iron is derived from phagocyte ferritin.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented to the dermatology OPD with umbilicated papules on his lower abdomen and inner thighs. History reveals that he is sexually active and the presence of similar lesions on his sexual partner. Microscopic examination of material expressed from the papule shows the following. The given microscopic image shows large (up to 35 μm), ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum where the sexually transmitted type is MCV - 2.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin or mucous membrane caused by a poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is about 300 nm in size, the largest pathogenic poxvirus in humans. There are 4 types of molluscum contagiosum virus (MCVs) - MCV-1 to -4. The most prevelent is MCV-1 and MCV-2 is most often sexually transmitted.

Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules. A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

Tzanck smear: intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson–Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30–35 μm)

Microscopic examination: Cuplike verrucous epidermal hyperplasia and Molluscum bodies: large (up to 35 μm), ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum.

Molluscum bodies contain numerous virions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of heartburn and regurgitation of food for the past few years. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy showed the following histopathological finding.  Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: This condition occurs as a complication of GERD
Obese white men are at a higher risk
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma
It affects the area above the gastroesophageal junction

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and biopsy findings showing intestinal metaplasia are suggestive of Barrett's esophagus which increases the risk of adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma.

Barrett's esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease, and it is estimated to occur in about 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation and sometimes dysphagia. Obese white men over the age of 60 years represent the highest-risk group.

It is characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, it is seen as the replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells. The greatest concern in Barrett's esophagus is that it confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

A histological image showing goblets cells is given below:

On endoscopy, Barrett's is recognized as areas of red, velvety mucosa extending proximally from the gastroesophageal junction. Such areas alternate with normal pale squamous esophageal mucosa. Diagnostic confirmation is by endoscopic biopsy. Biopsy reveals intestinal metaplasia characterized by the presence of goblet cells. Goblet cells are seen as cells with pale mucous vacuoles that stain blue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of progressive difficulty in breathing for the past 5 days. Her physical examination reveals a temperature of 37.2° C, heart rate of 88/min, respiratory rate of 22/min, and a blood pressure of 155/96mm Hg. The percussion note over both lung bases is stony dull and the chest x-ray shows a bilateral pleural effusion. Laboratory findings show Hemoglobin 11.2 g/dl, WBC count 3460/mm3, blood urea 27 mg/dl, and serum creatinine 3.4 mg/dl. Her ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibody test results are positive. Which of the following cardiac illness is most likely to be present in her?
questions.solution:
Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) and anti-double-stranded DNA antibody test is positive indicating the diagnosis of Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a complication of SLE, characterized by small, sterile vegetations that may occur anywhere over valves, chordae and endocardium.

Vegetations are often associated with severe valvulitis, characterized by fibrinoid necrosis of the valve and reflects the activation of complement and recruitment of Fc-receptor-bearing cells.

Other options:

  • Calcific aortic stenosis may be seen in older individuals as a consequence of age-associated wear and tear, involving tricuspid or bicuspid valves.
  • Although pericarditis is common in SLE, it is serous, not hemorrhagic.
  • Rheumatic heart disease is an immunologic disease and serologic tests would be positive for antistreptolysin O (ASO), not ANA.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops a fever, oliguria, periorbital edema, and smoky cola-colored urine  2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. Which of the following findings are most likely to be seen in the renal biopsy?

choices.text: Focal glomerular sclerosis on light microscopy
Hypercellular glomeruli with influx of leukocytes on light microscopy
Tram track appearance on PAS staining

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of fever, oliguria, periorbital edema, and smoky cola-colored are suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). The classic histologic picture of this disease shows hypercellular glomeruli with the influx of leucocytes (endocapillary proliferation).

PSGN is caused by immune complexes containing streptococcal antigens (M protein of cell wall) and specific antibodies. It is more commonly seen in children and they typically present with malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and hematuria (smoky or cola-colored urine) 1 to 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. The patients may also have mild proteinuria, periorbital edema, and mild to moderate hypertension.

In adults, the disease is more severe and the presentation and onset are atypical with features such as the sudden appearance of hypertension or edema, frequently with an elevation of BUN (blood urea nitrogen).

The characteristic electron microscopic findings are discrete, amorphous, electron-dense deposits called subepithelial humps (presumably representing the antigen-antibody complexes) and the presence of subendothelial deposits. 

Elevated titers of antibodies against many streptococcal antigens and a decrease in serum complement levels are also seen.

In 95% of the children, this disease is self-limiting. However, in some children and a large number of adults (40%), it may progress to a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis.

Other options:

Option A: Focal glomerular sclerosis on light microscopy is characteristically seen in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. It is primarily idiopathic but can occur in association with some conditions like HIV, heroin nephropathy, and morbid obesity. It presents as nephrotic syndrome in children and adults

Option C: Podocyte effacement is characteristically seen with minimal change disease. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

Option D: Tram track appearance on PAS staining is seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A teenager presents to the OPD with fever, malaise and lymphadenopathy. Heterophile agglutination test is positive, The causative virus uses the complement receptor ____________ to attach to and infect B cells?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described here is of infectious mononucleosis. The causative virus is the Epstein-Barr virus. It uses the complement receptor CD 21 to attach to and infect B cells.

EBV infects B lymphocytes and possibly epithelial cells of the oropharynx. The infection of B cells is latent; that is, there is no viral replication and the cells are not killed. However, B cells latently infected with EBV express viral proteins that result in the ability to propagate indefinitely in vitro.

CD 10, 22 are B cell markers but are not used by EBV to infect B cells.

CD 3 is a T cell marker.

questions.text: A child is brought with hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma. On testing, you find an isolated prolongation of prothrombin time. Which of the following clotting factors is likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma is suggestive of a bleeding disorder and that associated with an isolated prolonged prothrombin time shows that clotting factor VII is likely to be deficient in this patient.  

Prothrombin time (PT) assesses the extrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time (in seconds) needed for plasma to clot after the addition of an exogenous source of tissue thromboplastin and calcium ions. A prolonged PT can occur due to deficiencies/dysfunction of factors V, VII, X, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen.

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) assesses the intrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time needed for plasma to clot after the addition of kaolin (to activate XII), cephalin (substitutes platelet phospholipids), and calcium ions. aPTT is prolonged due to dysfunction of V, VIII, IX, X, XI, XII, prothrombin, and fibrinogen.  

Thus this shows that factor VII deficiency is associated with isolated prolongation of PT.

Clotting factor VII deficiency, otherwise known as Alexander's disease, is usually inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. It can present with recurrent episodes of bleeding into joints, muscles, and closed spaces that start spontaneously or following an injury. Diagnosis can be made by lab results of PT and aPTT and confirmed with factor VII assay. Patients are treated with recombinant factor VIIa.  

Other options:

Option B & C: Factor VIII and IX deficiency, otherwise known as hemophilia A & B respectively, are associated with isolated prolonged aPTT.

Option D: Factor II deficiency is associated with prolongation of both PT and aPTT.

questions.text: Detection of products of dead cells by inflammasome induces secretion of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Detection of products of dead cells by inflammasome induces secretion of interleukin-1 (IL-1).

Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death. Unlike classical apoptosis, pyroptosis is characterized by the release of inflammatory mediators. 

Apoptosis: The intrinsic mitochondrial and extrinsic death receptor-initiated pathways converge to activate a caspase cascade that mediates the final phase of apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway activates caspase 9, whereas the extrinsic pathway activates caspases 8 and 10. These caspases then activate caspase 3 and caspase 6. Activated caspases cause DNA degradation and nuclei fragmentation.

Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent distinct pathway of cell death induced by lipid peroxidation. The widespread peroxidation disrupts membrane function, which leads to the loss of plasma membrane permeability and results in cell death resembling necrosis. 

Necroptosis, as the name suggests, has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. Ligation of TNFR1 initiates necroptosis. This is a caspase-independent programmed cell death.

questions.solution:
Sirtuins increase insulin sensitivity (not resistance)

Sirtuins are a family of NAD-dependent protein deacetylases. They help in adapting to various environmental stresses, including food deprivation and DNA damage.

Sirtuins promote the expression of several genes whose products increase longevity. These include proteins that

  • Reduce apoptosis
  • Stimulate protein folding

  • Increase insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism (may be targeted for the treatment of diabetes).

Sirtuins level increases by caloric restriction and are present in red wine.

questions.text: Two sisters of age 25 and 18 years presented with bilateral painless progressive visual loss. After a detailed examination, a diagnosis of a rare inherited disease was made. The pedigree chart shown in the image below represents the pedigree chart of the family.  What is the pattern of inheritance seen here?
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in the pedigree chart is mitochondrial inheritance.

The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance. The mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is completely derived from the ovum. Therefore, when the mother is affected and the father is normal, all their children will be affected. 

However, children will not be affected if they are born to a normal mother and an affected father. Only the daughters of the affected mother will further transmit the disease to the next generations.

The condition described that shows this pattern of inheritance is Leber optic neuropathy. It is a neurodegenerative disease that leads to progressive bilateral loss of central vision. It is first noted between the age of 15 and 35 years and eventually leads to blindness.

 
Features of mitochondrial inheritance:
  • The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. The organs of the central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys are affected as they are most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Heteroplasmy is a phenomenon in which the individual has both wild-type and mutant type of mtDNA. 
  • Threshold effect is defined as a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA to be present in the mitochondria that can lead to oxidative dysfunction to manifest the disease.
  • The expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ. This is because there is a variable distribution of the normal and mutant mtDNA to the cells.

Other options:

Option A- Autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance is a type of Mendelian inheritance where both the alleles at a given gene locus are mutated. Characteristics of autosomal recessive inheritance:

  • Parents of affected individuals might not show the disease, however, the siblings might show the disease.
  • Heterozygous state individuals will be asymptomatic and the disease is manifested in the homozygous state.
  • The affected individual is most likely the product of a consanguineous marriage.
  • Examples of autosomal inheritance are cystic fibrosis, phenylketonuria, thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, etc.

Option B- X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance is a type of Mendelian inheritance where the mutant gene is present on the X-chromosome without a corresponding allele on the Y-chromosome. Characteristics are:

  • The affected male will not transmit the disease to the sons, but all his daughters will be carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous females have a 1 in 2 chance of receiving the mutant allele.
  • Examples of X-linked recessive inheritance are Duchenne muscular dystrophy, hemophilia A and B, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, etc.

Option C- X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance is a type of Mendelian inheritance where the dominant mutant allele is on the X-chromosome. It is characterized by:

  • An affected female transmits the disease to half of her sons and half of her daughters.
  • An affected male transmits the disease to all his daughters and none of his sons.
  • Examples of X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance are vitamin-D resistant rickets and Alport syndrome.

The clinical scenario of a child presenting with a mass in the abdomen, diarrhea, ecchymosis, hypertension, histopathology showing Homer-Wright pseudorosettes is suggestive of neuroblastoma.

Neuroblastoma is a tumor of the sympathetic nervous system in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic chain that originates from neural crest cells. The most common cause of familial predisposition is the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene mutation. It is predominantly seen in children less than 5 years of age. Patients present with a mass in the abdomen, ecchymosis or proptosis due to secondary lesions in the periorbital region, and elevated blood pressure due to increased levels of catecholamines in the blood.

In neonates, multiple cutaneous metastases cause deep blue discoloration of the skin called blueberry muffin baby. In children, neuroblastoma mostly arises from the adrenal medulla. On transsection, it is composed of grey-tan tissue with hemorrhage and areas of necrosis and calcification. A biopsy of the tumor gives a pathological diagnosis. Histology shows small, round blue cells with dark nuclei, scanty cytoplasm, and Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.

Urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) are elevated. CT or MRI to assess the mass and secondaries. The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumor and adjuvant chemotherapy. The drugs used from chemotherapy are carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, etoposide, and doxorubicin.

The image below shows a typical Homer-wright pseudorosette is seen in which tumor cells are arranged concentrically with a central space filled with eosinophilic fibrillary material:

Other options:

Option A: Hepatoblastoma is the most common childhood liver tumor. Histologically, it is composed of small polygonal embryonal cells that form trabeculae, acini, or papillary structures in the developing liver. The image below shows the histology of hepatoblastoma, which shows proliferating hepatoblasts consisting of round epithelial cells.

Option B: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a mesenchymal malignant tumor. Histologically, it comprises sheets of primitive round cells with skeletal muscle differentiation. The image below shows the histology of alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma and sheets of primitive round cells.

Option C: Nephroblastoma, also known as Wilms tumor, is the most common primary renal tumor in childhood. Histologically, it shows the classic triphasic pattern composed of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cell types.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man undergoes renal transplantation. Within minutes of completing the anastomosis, the transplanted kidney appears cyanotic & mottled, and it is found to be completely anuric. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Hyperacute rejection. Hyperacute rejection occurs when preformed anti-donor antibodies are present in the circulation of the recipient.

Hyperacute rejection:

  • Occurs within minutes or hours after transplantation.
  • Immunoglobulin and complement are deposited in the vessel wall, causing endothelial injury and fibrin-platelet thrombi.
  • Neutrophils rapidly accumulate within arterioles, glomeruli, and peritubular capillaries.
  • The kidney cortex then undergoes outright necrosis (infarction). Hence the transplant appears cyanotic & mottled.

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

The image shows a bone marrow biopsy needle. Thrombocytopenia is not an absolute contraindication for bone marrow biopsy. If the platelet count falls below 20,000 cells/μL, or if clinically warranted, platelet transfusion is performed before the procedure.

Indications:

  • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and pancytopenia
  • Evaluation of multiple myeloma, lymphoma, and myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors
  • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias
  • Evaluation of infections such as histoplasmosis, leishmaniasis, cryptococcosis, and Q fever

  • Severe hemophilia
  • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy
  • Severe bleeding disorders

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic demised from sudden cardiac death.  During the autopsy, the heart is enlarged, heavy, and flabby. A cardiac histopathologic image is shown below.  Which of the following cardiac conditions must he have developed?
questions.solution:
The history of alcoholism and sudden cardiac death with cardiac histopathology showing myocytes with ninja star-like nuclei suggests that the man must have developed dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM).

Dilated cardiomyopathy is the morphological and functional progressive cardiac dilatation and systolic dysfunction. To be considered DCM, the heart should not have any primary valvular abnormalities.

Causes of DCM include:

  • Genetic factors (familial in 50% of cases)
  • Direct toxic effects of alcohol and its metabolites (acetaldehyde)
  • Previous history of viral myocarditis
  • Exposure to cardiotoxic drugs such as cobalt
  • Iron overload  (hemochromatosis)
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy
  • Catecholamine effect causing Takotsubo cardiomyopathy 

Clinical features include the slow progression to congestive heart failure and symptoms and signs related to it. Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmias or progressive cardiac failures can occur. 

Histopathologically, myocytes will show hyperchromatic and highly distorted ninja star-like nuclei (non-specific finding).

Other options: 

Option A: Pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardium and is caused by infectious or immunologically mediated agents. Histologically, there can be a mild inflammatory infiltrate in the epipericardial fat. 

Option B: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a genetic disorder causing myocardial hypertrophy. This leads to a poorly compliant ventricle which causes abnormal diastolic filling as well as intermittent ventricular outflow obstruction. Histopathologically, there is massive myocytic hypertrophy and myofiber disarray.

Option D: Myocarditis is the inflammation of the myocardium that is primary in nature or caused by an infectious organism. Histopathologically, it is characterized by interstitial inflammatory infiltrates that are associated with degenerating or apoptotic myocytes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old, chronic alcoholic male developed dyspnoea, fever, and hypotension after being administered 2 units of fresh frozen plasma. Oxygen saturation of 88% and bilateral lung infiltrates were seen in the chest x-ray. He was diagnosed to have a Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI). What is the duration within which TRALI occurs after a transfusion?
questions.solution:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury(TRALI) occurs during or within 6 hours of transfusion.

TRALI is a sudden onset of respiratory failure resulting from the transfusion of donor fresh frozen plasma and platelets that contain high-titer of anti-HLA antibodies. These antibodies bind recipient leukocytes and aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature, releasing mediators that increase capillary permeability. 

The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis:

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung
  • Second hit - the aggravating factor (most commonly MHC class II  antibodies) present in the transfused blood product activates the primed neutrophils

TRALI is a severe fatal complication of blood transfusion. The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. Recipients with a history of pre-existing lung diseases, smoking, chronic alcohol use, mechanical ventilation and cancer surgeries are at increased risk of developing TRALI. 

The recipient develops symptoms of hypotension, fever, hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates visible on the chest X-ray.

Treatment is supportive, and patients usually recover without sequelae. The incidence of TRALI has been reduced by choosing males and nulliparous women as donors.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with excessive weight gain, easy bruising, striae, and glucose intolerance. After appropriate workup, she is diagnosed with an adrenocortical adenoma. Which of the following layers of the adrenal gland are involved in this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome caused by the adrenocortical adenoma. The layer of the adrenal gland involved in Cushing's syndrome is zona fasciculata. 

Cushing's syndrome is caused by elevated glucocorticoid (cortisol) production. It can be endogenous (intrinsic hormone production) or exogenous (consumption of excessive glucocorticoids). The endogenous causes can also be classified as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) dependent or independent. 

ACTH is released by the anterior pituitary in response to corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) released by the hypothalamus. It signals the zona fasciculata of the adrenal gland to produce more glucocorticoids by a feedback mechanism. In some instances, ectopic production of cortisol is unresponsive to ACTH released by the pituitary gland. Thus, hypercortisolism can be ACTH-dependent or independent. 

60-70% of cases of endogenous hypercortisolism are caused by ACTH-secreting pituitary adenomas.

5-10% of ACTH secretion is by ectopic tumors, most commonly being small-cell carcinoma of the lung. 

The most common cause of ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome is primary adrenal neoplasm as seen in this case.

Zona fasciculata Glucocorticoids Cortisol
Zona reticularis Sex steroids Estrogens and androgens
Adrenal medulla Catecholamines Epinephrine

questions.text: An autopsy is done on a plastic factory worker. The gross specimen of the liver is shown in the image below. Reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces (arrows) are present. The asterisk marks the normal liver tissue. Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm that has equal gender predilection. The tumor may occur at any site, but most often involves skin, soft tissue, breast, and liver. They are locally invasive and can readily metastasize.

Hepatic angiosarcomas are associated with exposure to carcinogens.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with abdominal pain, bloody stools, and elevated blood pressure. He is a known case of chronic hepatitis B. The arterial biopsy finding of this patient is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chronic hepatitis B infection and arterial biopsy findings of fibrinoid necrosis suggests a likely diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). 

Polyarteritis nodosa is a vasculitis syndrome that causes segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation in small and medium-sized arteries. It is often superimposed with aneurysm or thrombosis. 

About one-third of the patients with PAN are noted to have chronic hepatitis B which causes the formation of HBsAg-HbsAb immune complexes being deposited in the vessel walls.

Histologically, during the acute phase, there is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall along with fibrinoid necrosis and luminal thrombosis. Fibrinoid necrosis is usually the result of the deposition of immune complexes and plasma proteins in the arterial wall. On biopsy, fibrinoid necrosis appears as bright pink and amorphous deposits in the vessel wall. 

Clinical features include rapidly accelerating hypertension caused by the involvement of renal arteries, abdominal pain, and bloody stools due to vascular gastrointestinal lesions. 

Other options:

Option A- Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a vascular pathology seen in severe hypertension. Arterial biopsy findings show an onion-skin appearance that consists of a concentric arrangement of smooth muscle cells with a thickened and re-duplicated basement membrane.

The image below shows the characteristic onion skin appearance of a renal arteriole.

Option C- Monckeberg medial sclerosis is a vascular pathology of aging characterized by calcifications accumulating in the medial layers of muscular arteries. Since there is no vascular compromise (no luminal narrowing), it is usually an accidental finding.

The image below shows calcific deposits (deep purple on H&E staining) in the arterial wall.

Option D- Giant cell arteritis/temporal arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis affecting large- to small-sized arteries of the head and is commonly seen in the elderly. Patients usually present with constitutional symptoms and symptoms specific to the artery involved:

  • cerebral artery, temporal artery- facial pain, headache
  • ophthalmic artery- sudden onset visual loss, diplopia

Arterial biopsy findings consist of granulomatous inflammation with internal elastic lamina fragmentation and T-cell infiltration. The image below shows internal elastic lamina fragmentation (black arrow) and giant cells (yellow arrow) in a cerebral artery.

questions.text: Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm are seen in________
questions.solution:
Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm are seen in Langerhans cells.

They are pentalaminar tubules often with a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket like appearance, which contain protein langerin. Although a part of normal Langerhans histology they also provide a mechanism to differentiate Langerhans cell histocytes from other proliferative cells.

questions.text: Histologic sections of follicular carcinoma of the thyroid would characteristically reveal:

choices.text: An amyloid stroma intermixed with neoplastic C cells
Blood vessel and capsular invasion by malignant thyroid follicles
Diagnostic nuclear changes including “Orphan Annie eyes”, nuclear grooves
Papillary fronds with fibrovascular cores and psammoma bodies

questions.solution:
Histological section of follicular carcinoma of thyroid may reveal blood vessel and capsular invasion by malignant thyroid follicles.

The four major histologic subtypes of thyroid carcinoma are papillary, follicular, medullary, and undifferentiated (anaplastic).

  • Papillary carcinomas of the thyroid are composed of papillary structures with fibrovascular cores, while follicular carcinomas typically show a microfollicular pattern.
  • Features consistent with papillary carcinoma, include optically clear nuclei (‘ground-glass’, or ‘Orphan Annie eyes’), nuclear grooves, calcospherites (psammoma bodies), and intranuclear cytoplasmic pseudo inclusions.
  • Medullary carcinoma is characterized by its amyloid stroma, it's genetic (familial) associations and its elaboration of calcitonin and other substances.
  • Anaplastic carcinoma is seen in individuals over the age of 50. It is characterized by the anaplastic spindle or giant cells with frequent mitoses. This tumor is characterized by rapid growth and a poor prognosis.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: The lepidic growth pattern in histology is seen in which of the following epithelial lung tumors?
questions.solution:
Histologically lepidic growth patterns are seen in adenocarcinoma of the lung.

It refers to the pattern of spread of the tumor in which the tumor cells “crawl” along normal-appearing alveolar septae and resembles butterflies resting on a fence.

Tumors of 3 cm or less in diameter characterized by lepidic growth pattern without stromal invasion are now called adenocarcinoma in situ (formerly called bronchoalveolar carcinoma).

Adenocarcinomas grow in various patterns, including acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid with mucin formation. Tumor cells are positive for mucin and thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1).

It is the most common form of lung cancer. It is an invasive malignant epithelial tumor with glandular differentiation or mucin production by the tumor cells. It is usually located peripherally (it arises from terminal bronchiole).  Molecular genetics show frequent mutations in EGFR, ALK, ROS, MET, and RET (Receptor tyrosine kinase genes) or KRAS mutations.

questions.text: The cell marked in the image below predominantly plays a role in which of the following hypersensitivity reactions?
questions.solution:
The cell marked in the image is a mast cell stained with toluidine blue. Mast cells play an important role in type-I hypersensitivity reactions.

Mast cell granules contain acid proteoglycan that binds basic blue such as toluidine blue. Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin-stained sections, and special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to visualize their granules.

Mast cells are a part of innate immunity and are widely distributed in connective tissues. They play an important role in immediate hypersensitivity and both acute and chronic inflammation.

Mast cells express a receptor on their surface that binds to the Fc portion of the IgE antibody. When an antigen binds to IgE antibodies on the surface of the mast cell, they get activated and degranulate. This results in the release of the following:

  • Granule contents: Histamine, chymase, tryptase, heparin.
  • Lipid mediators: Leucotriene C4, D4, prostaglandin D2, platelet-activating factor.
  • Cytokines: Tumor necrosis factor, interleukin-1

These mediators released from mast cells play an important role in the pathogenesis of immediate/type 1 hypersensitivity.

The image given below shows the sequence of events in immediate (type 1) hypersensitivity.

Some of the important disorders associated with mast cell activity are bronchial asthma, urticaria, mastocytosis, interstitial cystitis and neurofibroma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with increased fatigue, low-grade fevers, and night sweats. Physical examination reveals several small, rubbery, mobile, non-tender supraclavicular lymph nodes. The lymph node biopsy findings are shown in the image below. Immunophenotyping shows CD15+, CD30+, and PAX5+. Activation of which of the following factors occurs in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the image showing Reed-Sternberg cells are suggestive of a diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma. Activation of the transcription factor NF-κB is a common event in classical Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

NF-κB may be activated by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. EBV+ tumor cells express latent membrane protein-1 (LMP-1), a protein encoded by the EBV genome that transmits signals that upregulate NF-κB. Activation of NF-κB may occur in EBV tumors as a result of the acquired loss-of-function mutations in TNF alpha-induced protein 3 (TNFAIP3). (Option D)

Activation of NF-κB by EBV or other mechanisms rescues “crippled” germinal center B cells that cannot express Igs from apoptosis, eventually leading to the formation of Reed-Sternberg cells. TNF α, IL-10, and TGF beta are involved in cross-talk between Reed-Sternberg cells and other normal cells in classical forms of Hodgkin's lymphoma. (Option A and B)

Reed-Sternberg cell: It is a giant cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space.

Clinical features of Hodgkin's lymphoma - Typical presentation involves lymphadenopathy/ mass with B symptoms, which include fever, night sweats, and weight loss.

Diagnosis - Requires microscopic findings and immunophenotyping findings to correlate. Microscopy of lymph nodes shows the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

questions.text: The gross appearance of a liver pictured while conducting an autopsy of a chronic alcoholic is as shown below. This finding is a result of the activation of which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
The gross appearance of the liver showing classic micronodular cirrhosis seen in alcoholic steatofibrosis is a result of the activation of stellate cells.

Stellate cells :

Scarring of the liver (cirrhosis) in which hepatocytes are surrounded by fibrosis (with or without a regenerative response) represents a common endpoint for chronic liver disease. The principal cell type involved in scar deposition in the liver is the hepatic stellate cell. 

Hepatic stellate cells are present in the space of Disse and store lipids, including vitamin A. They are mesenchymal in origin. But in several cases of acute and chronic injury to the liver, these cells are activated and differentiate into highly fibrogenic myofibroblasts.

The activation of stellate cells can be varied and includes the following:

  • Inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α) are produced by Kupffer cells, macrophages, etc.
  • Altered interactions with the extracellular matrix
  • Toxins and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

These activated stellate cells are then converted into myofibroblasts through signals transmitted by platelet-derived growth factor receptor β and by several cytokines (TGF-β, IL-17) and chemokines. Extracellular matrix deposition and scarring commence in the space of Disse. Eventually, the surviving hepatocytes are encircled by fibrous septa and give rise to diffuse scarring (cirrhosis). Hepatocytes replicate in an effort to restore the parenchyma which gives rise to regenerative nodules, a feature seen in most cirrhotic livers.

There are three distinctive, overlapping forms of alcoholic liver injury:

  • Hepatic steatosis (fatty liver)
    • Fatty change is completely reversible if there is abstention from further intake of alcohol.
    • Starts in the centrilobular area
  • Alcoholic (steato) hepatitis
    • Ballooning degeneration and necrosis
    • Mallory–Denk bodies/ Mallory hyaline - These are tangled skeins of intermediate filaments such as keratin 8 and keratin 18 that are partially degraded and ubiquitinated.
    • Neutrophilic reaction
  • Alcoholic steatofibrosis
    • Perisinusoidal fibrosis and sclerosis of the central vein
    • Micronodular/ Laennec cirrhosis
    • Irreversible

Continued damage of the liver with alcohol progresses to portal/ periportal fibrosis, and then to bridging fibrosis and cirrhosis, which is micronodular (“Laennec cirrhosis”) The characteristic diffuse nodularity of the surface is induced by the underlying fibrous scarring.

Other options:

Option B: Kupffer cells are hepatic macrophages, which are responsible for removing cellular and microbial debris from the circulation, and also for secreting cytokines involved in defense.

Option C: Hepatic stem cells are undifferentiated, pluripotential cells and reside around the canals of Hering.

Option D: The endothelial cells are typically flat cells, each with a central nucleus, and they are joined to each other by junctional complexes. Their cytoplasm contains numerous transcytotic vesicles.

questions.text: Activation of which of the following caspases occurs in pyroptosis?
questions.solution:
Pyroptosis is a form of apoptosis that occurs due to the activation of caspase 1.

Pyroptosis occurs due to the release of fever-inducing cytokine interleukin-1 (IL-1). Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death. Unlike classical apoptosis, pyroptosis is characterized by the release of inflammatory mediators. 

Apoptosis- The intrinsic mitochondrial and extrinsic death receptor-initiated pathways converge to activate a caspase cascade that mediates the final phase of apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway activates caspase 9 whereas the extrinsic pathway activates caspases 8 and 10. These caspases then activate caspase 3, and caspase 6. Activated caspases cause DNA degradation and nuclei fragmentation.

Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent distinct pathway of cell death induced by lipid peroxidation. The widespread peroxidation disrupts membrane function which leads to the loss of plasma membrane permeability and results in cell death resembling necrosis. 

Necroptosis, as the name suggests has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. Ligation of TNFR1 initiates necroptosis. This is a caspase-independent programmed cell death.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of abnormal skin pigmentation over his forearms and face. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. Which stain has been used to identify his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features suggest a diagnosis of hemochromatosis. Prussian blue stain is used to identify this condition. On this stain, the hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes appear blue in color. 

Hemochromatosis occurs due to excessive iron absorption that leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs. The involvement of organs occurs in the following order:

  • Liver
  • Pancreas 
  • Myocardium
  • Endocrine organs (pituitary gland, adrenal gland, thyroid, and parathyroid glands)
  • Joints
  • Skin

It can be primary hemochromatosis (inherited disorder) or secondary hemochromatosis (accumulation of iron due to other causes). The adult form of primary hemochromatosis usually occurs due to mutations of the HFE gene.

Clinical features include:

  • Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly
  • Diabetes mellitus due to destruction of pancreatic islets
  • Slate-gray color skin pigmentation due to increased melanin production
  • Cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy)
  • Acute synovitis due to excessive deposition of calcium pyrophosphate that produces disabling polyarthritis known as pseudogout
  • Atrophic testes secondary to pituitary involvement

The image below shows a slide of liver microscopy that has been stained with Perls Prussian blue stain. The hepatocellular iron appears blue due to the stain.

Other options:

Option A: Masson trichrome stain can be used to demonstrate collagen. 

Option B: Congo red stain can be used for demonstrating the accumulation of amyloid.

Option C: Sudan black stain is a fat-soluble dye that is used to demonstrate lipid inclusions.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presented with complaints of red-colored urine in the morning. The CBC revealed anemia, low serum iron, and an elevated reticulocyte count. Flow cytometry of blood revealed the following finding. Which of the following gene mutations is most likely responsible for the given condition?
questions.solution:
The flow cytogram shows a population of red blood cells deficient in both CD55 and CD59 (in the left lower quadrant), characteristic of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), which is caused due to mutation in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A (PIGA) gene.

PIGA encodes for an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins.  It is the only hemolytic anemia caused by an acquired genetic defect.

The glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) is a phospholipid that helps certain proteins anchor to the cell membrane. Inactivation of PIGA causes a deficiency of these GPI-linked proteins. PIGA gene is X-linked and is subject to lyonization. As a result, a mutation that occurs even in a single hematopoietic stem cell may affect all of its clonal progeny (red cells, white cells, and platelets) that are deficient in GPI- linked proteins.

In PNH, the blood cells are deficient in three GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity: 

  • Decay accelerating factor, or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis, or CD59
  • C8 binding protein

Disease manifestations:

  • Red cells deficient in GPI-linked factors are abnormally susceptible to lysis or injury by complement. It results in intravascular hemolysis, which is caused by the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex. The RBCs have a tendency to lyse during the night due to a slight decrease in blood pH during sleep.
  • The loss of heme iron in the urine leads to iron deficiency anemia.
  • In about 40% of the patients, there is venous thrombosis, involving the hepatic, portal, or cerebral veins. Thrombosis is the leading cause of disease-related death in PNH.
     

Diagnosis - Flow cytometry:

The diagnosis of PNH is made by flow cytometry. It shows a population of red cells that is deficient in both CD55 and CD59 (left-lower quadrant in the image below). Also, a second population of red cells, which are derived from residual normal hematopoietic stem cells may be seen, which are positive for CD55 and CD59 (right-upper quadrant in the image below).

Other options:

b. PML/RARA gene mutation is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia, which is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia.

c. Mutaionin tyrosine kinase JAK2 is associated with polycythemia vera. It is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets.

d. BCR-ABL gene mutation is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia.

The incidental X-ray findings showing extensive calcification of the femoral arteries in this patient which are strongly suggestive of Monckeberg medial sclerosis. It is caused due to calcification in the medial walls of muscular arteries starting at the internal elastic lamina.

It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. Since the calcifications do not encroach on the vessel lumen and are usually not clinically significant. Therefore, it is usually an incidental finding as in this case.

Therefore, the radiograph of the patient does not appear like the above.

DVT most commonly occurs in the calf veins. DVT is usually asymptomatic. Some patients may present with pain in the calf or thigh. Duplex ultrasound is used in identifying venous thrombosis.
