questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who is a known case of neurofibromatosis type 2 presented with a headache for a few days and  2 episodes of seizures. MRI brain shows a tumor. The biopsy of the tumor specimen is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of headache, seizures, and histopathology showing the syncytial or whorled clusters of epithelial tumour cells in a female patient of neurofibromatosis type 2 is highly suggestive of meningioma.

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumours, usually attached to the dura. They are predominantly seen in females and in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2, which is an autosomal disorder associated with multiple meningiomas, schwannomas, and ependymomas.

They arise from the meningothelial cells or arachnoid cap cells. The most common karyotypic abnormality is the loss of the long arm of chromosome 22. Meningiomas often express hormone receptors (eg: Progesterone), hence, they may grow rapidly in pregnancy.

Meningiomas are rubbery, rounded, or bosselated dural masses. They compress the underlying brain tissue. They present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits. 

The tumour spreads in a sheet-like manner along the surface of the dura causing reactive hyperostotic changes in adjacent bones. They are mostly located in cerebral convexities. The lesions may be finely gritty due to numerous psammomatous calcifications. 

Grades of meningioma based on histologic subtypes by WHO are:

Grade I is the benign meningioma that has a relatively low risk of recurrence or aggressive growth. The histologic patterns are:

  • Meningothelial or syncytial (most common). They are clusters of epitheliod tumour cells that sit in tight groups without visible cell membranes as shown below.
  • Fibroblastic
  • Transitional
  • Psammomatous

The image below shows a meningothelial or syncytial pattern:

 

Grade II is the atypical meningioma which has a high recurrence rate and more aggressive local growth. Histologic patterns are clear cell and chordoid. 

Grade III is the anaplastic or malignant meningioma is highly aggressive often resembling carcinoma or sarcoma. Histologic patterns are papillary and rhabdoid.

The image below shows a well-defined, hyper-intense, and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline suggestive of meningioma.

 

When the meningiomas are small and asymptomatic, observation with serial MRI studies is done. When larger and symptomatic, they should be excised. External beam radiotherapy is done for unresectable tumours.

Other options:

Option B- Schwannomas are benign tumours arising from the Schwann cells. Acoustic or vestibular schwannoma arising from the vestibular portion of the eighth nerve is the most common schwannoma. Histopathologically they are composed of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B respectively. In Antoni A area, a central nuclear-free area ramified by palisading nuclei is termed as Verocay bodies. Schwannomas are associated with NF2, but they typically arise from the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII), leading to hearing loss and balance problems, not headaches and seizures. 

The image below shows the histology of schwannoma.

Option C- Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumour seen predominantly in children. Histopathologically Homer Wright rosettes formed by tumour cells are seen as shown below.

Option D- Oligodendroglioma arises from the glial cells. A histopathologically delicate network of anastomosing capillaries resembling chicken wire is seen as shown below.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presented with a history of fatigability, weight loss, anorexia, and rubbery swellings in his neck and armpits for the past 3 months. On examination, cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy was detected along with hepatosplenomegaly. Investigations revealed mild anemia, normal platelet count, with a leukocytosis of 60,000/mm3 with 75% lymphocytes. Immunophenotyping reveals CD 19+,CD20+, CD21+,CD22+, CD 23+, CD5+ and CyclinD1 negative. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and peripheral smear are suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL)

The differentiating point between CLL and SLL is that in CLL: absolute lymphocyte count is >5000 per mm³ and in SLL:<5000 per mm³. It is the most common leukemia among adults in the western world.

Proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL/SLL.

  • The chromosomal defects:
    • Deletion of 13q (commonest and has a good prognosis)
    • Deletion of 11q
    • Trisomy 12q
    • Deletion of 17p (poor prognosis)

In CLL, B cells originate from naive B cell or Pre/Post Germinal Centre memory B cell. CLL arises in the lymph node.

The peripheral blood smear in cases of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a "convent-girl" appearance. The small round lymphocytes (indicated by arrow) have condensed chromatin, and scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells may get disrupted while preparing the smears, producing so-called smudge cells (indicated by arrowhead).

Leukocyte count is highly variable; leukopenia in marrow involvement or leukocytosis. Hypogammaglobulinemia can be seen. 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells

Peripheral smear findings in CLL:

  • Numerous small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm
  • Smudge cells (artefacts due to disrupted tumor cells which lack vimentin)
  • Spherocytes (due to coexisting Autoimmune hemolytic anemia [AIHA])
  • Nucleated RBCs (due to premature release of progenitors in face of severe anemia, marrow infiltration tumor, or both)

The classical immunophenotypic feature of CLL is CD 19+,CD20+, CD21+,CD22+, CD 23+, CD5+ .The immunophenotype of CLL demonstrates coexpression of the B lymphocyte lineage marker CD 19 with the T lymphocyte marker CD5.

CLL most often affects elderly persons, many of whom are asymptomatic for many years. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly, easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia are frequent findings. 

On lymph node biopsy:

Lymph node shows diffuse effacement composed of small lymphocytes admixed, with variable numbers of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates referred to as proliferation centers, which contain mitotically active cells.

 

Expectant management is the treatment of choice for asymptomatic patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Chemotherapy and monoclonal antibodies are used when there is

  • Progressive marrow failure- worsening anemia, thrombocytopenia
  • Progressive splenomegaly
  • Progressive lymphadenopathy
  • Presence of constitutional symptoms like weight loss, fever, night sweats, etc.

Important drugs used in the management of CLL are fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, bendamustine, and rituximab.

 

Other options:

Myeloid sarcoma (chloroma, extramedullary myeloid tumor, granulocytic sarcoma) is defined by the WHO as a tumor mass consisting of myeloid blasts, with or without maturation, occurring at extramedullary sites. It is called "chloroma" due to its peculiar green color, caused by myeloperoxidase, which fades in a few hours. Arbiskov cells are seen in chloroma.

Bones affected are orbit (most common), skull, paranasal sinuses, sternum, ribs, vertebrae, and pelvis.

 

Peripheral smear of CLL.

 

Mantle cell lymphoma :

The primary difference between immunophenotype of CLL/SLL and Mantle cell lymphoma is CD23

Mantle cell lymphoma (option 2): CD 19+, CD 20+, CD21+, CD22+,CD23 (-), CD 5+

Follicular lymphoma (option 3): CD 79b+, CD 19+, CD 10+, CD 20+, CD22+

 Mantle-cell lymphoma arises from the mantle-zone B cells as the IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation (naive B cells). They  have an (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and overexpression of cyclin D1. It is seen in fifth and sixth decades of life and has male predominance

Features:

  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Splenomegaly
  • Multifocal mucosal involvement of small bowel and colon – lymphomatoid polyposis

Histology :

  • Nodal tumor cells may surround reactive germinal centers to produce a nodular appearance at low power, or diffusely efface the node.
  • Typically, the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply clefted (cleaved) nuclear contours
  • Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centers are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively

Chronic myelogenous leukemia. 

CML is primarily a disease of adults but also occurs in children and adolescents. The peak incidence is in the fifth to sixth decades of life.

The presence of a chimeric BCR-ABL is created by a reciprocal (9;22)(q34;q11) translocation (the so-called Philadelphia chromosome [Ph]). This is detected by cytogenetics, FISH, or PCR.

Mild-to-moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis.  Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction. Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

Peripheral blood - Leukocytosis, often exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3 which consists predominantly of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils. Blasts usually make up less than 10% of the circulating cells. Platelets - usually increased

Marrow -The marrow is markedly hypercellular because of massively increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors, which usually include an elevated proportion of eosinophils and basophils.

Megakaryocytes are also increased and usually include small, dysplastic forms. Erythroid progenitors are present in normal or mildly decreased numbers. Increased deposition of reticulin is typical, but overt marrow fibrosis is rare early in the course. Low LAP score
